column4: It crashed or something and I can't start it back up because apparently Google sees the zombie as the process already running
Google?  Chrome?
The GUI would update every 5 sec for example, and the CLI would be from pressing enter.
Virtual = Swap.  True
So why do most of my processes show virtual memory usage in the hundreds of MiB while total swap usage just shows 244 KiB?
Not a guru in linux, so not sure.  What command you using?
No command, just looking at System Monitor with most of the Memory columns enabled
My system monitor only had Memory (RAM) and Swap (VMemory)
Yeah that's in the Resources tab, it's the Processes tab where I'm not sure what the memory values exactly mean
are you talking about the processes?
I think that memory is not current, but accumulative.  How much it has loaded from the start.  Mine is just rising only.
NvM, it just dropped.
Hmm... Well I've seen it drop before, though the one I monitor the most is Firefox which is notorious for memory leaks (I constantly need to restart it because memory gets full and starts using swap)
The Mem in the processes is RAM.  Some may go to SWAP, but it's MEMORY + SWAP
If I remember correctly, resident memory = physical memory, which is usually slightly higher than memory
Physical memory is memory.  Only reason it's normally lower because the OS uses some.
I guess what's really needed is proper documentation on exactly what the columns mean. It's not in the help files and so far haven't found anything online.
It's clear that they don't mean what I (and albeit most people) think they mean, especially the virtual memory column which adds up to be much higher than total physical+swap usage
True, but that's linux in general.  I believe the memory column in processes is revering memory usage.  Makes no distinguation between physical or swap.
LOL  it's late, and my typing is going down hill.  :P
night
